Short Summary
Error and Loss is a philosophy
of science and religion. It examines a fundamental, 
unacknowledged error in the world-view of our age, as well as the
immense loss caused by this error—a loss that deeply affects the
quality of our lives. A recognition of the error opens up a fresh way of looking at the world, one which casts the current debates regarding science, religion, and atheism in a new light, since all sides share the unexamined belief that Error and Loss exposes. In the light of Error and Loss, in fact, the debate dissolves, and is replaced by a different way of conceiving of reality. 
I am a math and physics teacher who has studied religious ideas intensively (I have an MAR from Yale Divinity School and a BA in Chinese Literature from Yale College, and have studied source criticism at the Vatican University). 7 years ago I wrote the first draft of Error and Loss during a four-week retreat at the cabin in Piemonte, Italy, that is pictured on the overlay to my Indiegogo video. I am now asking the Indiegogo community to support me while I return to the cabin for a longer period of time (5 months) to bring the book into final form. 
The Book
Certainly many people today experience, at least sporadically, a feeling of awe and wonder at our existence, our world, our
universe. Yet this awe and wonder is in most cases qualified
by a kind of deadness hovering always in the background—qualified in
a way that it was not for earlier peoples. This deadening comes
from the thought that our existence, our experience, and the specific objects
of our experience can be explained by, or are explicable in
principle, by the powerful reasonings of our natural sciences.
When physicists speak of a “Theory of Everything” they express
this idea in a nutshell.
Error and Loss does not at all
propose erasing scientific advances or technological wonders. It does
not look to return to animistic times of ignorance, superstition, and
brutality, times it in no way attempts to idealize. It is not a New
Age work. It is written by a math and physics teacher and
its tool is transparently clear reasoning. The problem I attack in
our scientific world-view is not that it employs cold reason at the
expense of poetry, but that it does not reason well or
consistently enough. Specifically, it makes unexamined
assumptions which carry extremely significant but overlooked
implications. Error and Loss pinpoints these, following out
their consequences and driving them home. In particular, Error and Loss examines the implications of our belief in the independent existence of a world outside of our consciousness, arguing that these extend much further than is generally acknowledged, when acknowledged at all.
Despite its pessimistic-sounding title,
Error and Loss is actually an optimistic book, one that
believes that we can, if we see through the fundamental error of our
age, have the best of both worlds: the triumphs of scientific understanding and the
magic—not the surface magic, but the magic from the depths—that
enriched the lives of earlier times in a way that we are profoundly
nostalgic for. And this is not just because we would like to have
more magic in our lives, but because, if seen clearly for once, that
magic is there.
The Project
I have already written a first draft of
Error and Loss. I wrote it during a four-week stay in the hut mentioned above. This hut is a three-hour walk from the closest
village and a two-hour hike from the nearest road. There, 1500 meters above sea level, the main
events of the day are the rising and setting of the sun and the
convolutions of the weather. There is no electricity, and in order to
get cell phone reception I have to climb for another hour up onto a
ridge. I cook my meals with wood gathered from the forest floor. I
eat rice and lentils and oatmeal and, in the summer months, potatoes
and lettuces from a small garden. 
While I have tried to work on
revisions of Error and Loss in more civilized locations, these
lack the isolation, quiet, and distance from technology that allow me
to come into touch with what I am trying to do. I am now asking you,
the Indiegogo community, to fund a longer retreat into nature, back
to this hut, so that I can thoroughly revise my current draft and
return with a finished product—an accessible, practical,
easy-to-grasp philosophy that I believe can help remove a terrible
error and make good an awful loss.
Specifically, I would like to go into
the mountains on April 1st, 2015, and remain there until the end of August. (I will come down occasionally to stock up on
food and other necessities.) I will have an initial
version finished by July 1st, at which time I will return
to civilization for a week to type it up and send a pdf for review to
selected readers and to my sponsors. I will then return to the hut and put the finishing
touches on the manuscript. At the end of August  I will return to
civilization, type up, pdf, and bind the final version, and then send
it to my sponsors. 

A next step will be to find an agent
and a publisher for the book, but the Indiegogo-funded project ends
with the mailing of the copies by September 30. Of course I will
notify all of my Indiegogo supporters upon successful publication
of the book, and offer them signed copies. This step, however, is too
subject to the vagaries of the publishing world to set fixed dates
to, and so is not part of my concrete proposal.
I will be taking an unpaid leave of
absence from my job as math and physics teacher in Hasliberg, Switzerland, in order to work on
this project. I can only afford to do this if my expenses during the
months away are covered: health insurance, rent on my small studio,
food, travel, and the modest support I provide to my three children. 
$2500 per month will cover these costs,
and I am asking to be supported from April 1st till the end of August. If I can raise $12,500, this gig is on. As this is a fixed funding campaign, your contribution will be refunded to you in the event that my goal of $12,500 is not reached within 30 days. This guarantees that your money will not be used to support an only partially funded project. It's all or nothing.
Who I amI was born in California and grew up in Massachusetts and in Switzerland. My senior project in high school was an extended essay on the scientific Weltanschauung. I attended Yale College where I studied first Philosophy and then, in order to read Zen and Taoist texts in the original, Chinese Language and Literature. After a year in Rome taking courses at the Pontificia Universitas Gregoriana I completed an academic degree (MAR) at Yale Divinity School, focusing primarily on Biblical Hebrew and the Hebrew Bible. I simultaneously earned my teaching certification in high school mathematics, which I later extended, after a two year study of physics and physics pedagogy at Smith College, to include physics as well. After teaching in Rome for two years I went on to teach math and physics for nineteen years at the Ecole d'Humanite in Hasliberg, Switzerland. I was appointed Director of the Ecole in 2009 and served in this post until summer, 2014. I am a certified ski touring guide and licensed paragliding pilot. I have published a series of short mystery stories in Alfred Hitchcock Mystery Magazine, and am currently looking for a publisher for my novel, Double, Double, a mystery set against the controversy over who wrote Shakespeare's plays. I have three children, Joshua, Sonia, and Caleb, aged 23, 19, and 15.My interest in the philosophies of science and religion and their relationship goes back to a moment when, as a 16-year-old walking along Sparks Street in Cambridge, Massachusetts, I was struck by the circular nature of any justification for the validity of reasoned argument. I remember this moment distinctly—the fountain at the fork between Brattle and Craigie Streets, the tall  trees in full leaf, the erratic traffic. story:
A Las Ocho

José Benegas y Roberto Cachanosky son dos de los más importantes analistas de la actualidad política y económica de la Argentina.

Sus prediccciones han sido siempre certeras y han presentado sus opiniones sin tapujos y sin pelos en la lengua, cosa que incluso les ha costado su participación en los medios de comunicación tradicionales. Se han ganado la enemistad del gobierno, al punto de ser ellos y sus auspiciantes acosados por el mismo a través de operaciones de prensa y de la AFIP.

Con A Las Ocho, podrás acceder a su opinión y análisis político-económico en forma diaria sin depender de favores del estado o de empresas que son constantemente condicionadas por el mismo.

A Las Ocho es un programa de veinte minutos diarios de lunes a viernes, a las ocho de la noche, disponible en vivo y luego en diferido por YouTube, financiado por la audiencia.

Los colaboradores, con esta campaña ayudarán así a dar el puntapié inicial para un nuevo tipo de programas de opinión política, que no dependan ni del estado, ni de hacer lobby, ni de empresas que están a merced de los gobiernos. Así, podrá disfrutarse de una opinión honesta y no afectada por intereses o dependencia económica.

El objetivo de recaudación de esta campaña será de USD 6.000, lo que permitirá tener el programa al aire por tres meses ininterrumpidos. Los Ciudadanos se convertirán en productores, colaborando en la difusión de sus ideas e incitando a otros ciudadanos y periodistas a hacer lo mismo.


Convertite en un Ciudadano-Productor

A Las Ocho requiere de tu colaboración para llegar a un total de USD 6.000, lo que permitirá a Benegas, Cachanosky y su equipo televisar (en vivo y en diferido) un total de 65 programas regulares (tres meses, de lunes a viernes), además de especiales cuando las circunstancias lo requieran.

Lo recaudado será para cubrir los costos de emisión y producción del programa, así como también de la infraestructura y puesta online de cada episodio.

En caso de no completarse el total, se emitirá una cantidad de programas proporcional a lo recaudado

Colaboradores Donando USD 20 o más, estás realmente comprometido con el éxito del programa. Aparecerás mencionado en la web en la lista de las personas a las que les interesa el país.

Productor Ciudadano: Donando USD 50 o más, te convertís en Productor Ciudadano. Recibirás un certificado (en PDF) firmado por los conductores del programa. Figurarás en los créditos finales del programa y en la página web.

Productor Ciudadano Asociado: Donando USD 200 o más, participás de una videoconferencia privada, con José Benegas, Roberto Cachanosky y otros siete Productores Asociados. Además, recibirás el certificado en PDF y tu nombre aparecerá en un lugar privilegiado de la página web y de los créditos finales.

Productor Ciudadano De Honor: Edición limitada. Solamente Ocho lugares. Donando USD 500 o más, podrás participar de la videoconferencia de producción del último programa del ciclo y de una de las videoconferencias privadas junto los Productores Ciudadanos. Además, tendrás un espacio en los créditos para auspiciar una frase compatible con el espíritu del programa, un lugar privilegiado en la página web como Productor Ciudadano de Honor y el correspondiente certificado en PDF.

Aún cuando se cumpla el objetivo de la campaña, podés seguir colaborando: los fondos extra se usarán para emitir más programas. Por ejemplo, en caso de recaudar USD 7000, se emitirán 75 programas en lugar de 65.


A Las Ocho, como punta de lanza

Que la Argentina cambie depende de que una gran cantidad de personas exponga la realidad política del país tal cual es, desenmascarando el juego macabro que hacen en conjunto el gobierno y la oposición.

Al mismo tiempo, es necesario poner en la opinión pública el conjunto de ideas que hizo de Argentina un país próspero y pionero en el mundo. Los medios de comunicación le han fallado a la ciudadanía, haciendo popular una cantidad de ideas perjudicial para ella y juzgándola moralmente con una serie de criterios falsos y culposos.

A fin de terminar con esta situación, A Las Ocho servirá para inspirar a otros a sumarse a un grupo de programas y medios hechos por los Ciudadanos y para los Ciudadanos.


Otras formas de colaborar

¡Todos pueden colaborar!

Corré la voz del programa entre todos tus conocidos y familiares a los que creas que les puede interesar. Compartiles la campaña fácilmente utilizando las herramientas sociales que te provee Indiegogo.

Mirá y disfrutá del programa todos los días y compartilo después en las redes sociales.

Patrocinadores Ciudadanos: ¿Estás interesado en publicitar en A Las Ocho y convertirlo en un éxito a largo plazo? Comunicate con la producción enviando un mail a alasochotv@gmail.com.

I present to you South Africa’s first Dagga Culture & Activism Magazine.

This publication aims to serve a niche market with the optimistic potential of reaching over 4 million subscribers.

Your support is critical in making this project reality.

Claim Your Culture. Claim Your Dagga Magazine.
Donate & share with like minded individuals.

Concept


Dagga Magazine pledge to donate R1 or more per copy sold, monthly, towards a trust to provide financial aid in legal support for all those who are being prosecuted under unjust dagga law. 

Rewards

For $1 or more – Receive a shout-out on Dagga Magazine’s Facebook Page
For $5 or more – Receive a copy of the first issue of Dagga Magazine. 
For $50 or more –  Receive a 12 Month Subscription to Dagga Magazine 
For $90 or more – 1x Small Ad in first issue +/- 75.692 mm x 52.88 mm 
For $160 or more – 1x Medium Ad in first issue +/- 112.917 mm x 60.215 mm
For $260 or more – 1 Full Page Ad in first issue.
For $105 000 or more become a General Sponsor.
For $500 000 or more become a Premium Sponsor
For $1 000 000 or more become a Gold Sponsor.
For $12 500 000 or more become a Platinum Sponsor.

editor@daggamagazine.com

www.daggamagazine.com 

Tweets by @DaggaMagazine

story:
Summary

America’s got a race problem. You know it. I know it. To make change, we have to get people talking — and listening — about race, about who they are, about their fears, misunderstandings, and dreams. 

Fiction is a great way to broach these topics. Discussing a book with imaginary characters who do and say real-seeming things gives readers a less threatening way to start talking about the hard stuff. 

In April, University of Wisconsin Press will publish Meet Me Halfway, my collection of nine interconnected short stories about race and racism in hyper-segregated Milwaukee, Wisconsin.  

This campaign will fund my Meet Me Halfway road trip to the 10 most segregated cities in America — Milwaukee, Detroit, Chicago, St. Louis, Cleveland, Philadelphia, Boston, New York, Miami, and Los Angeles — to reach out to readers and to contribute to some long-overdue conversations about race. 

Think of it as a book tour+plus: I’ll do the readings at bookstores and colleges, but I will also make myself available to churches, schools, community groups, and workplaces, to facilitate conversations based on one or more of the Meet Me Halfway stories. I might also take a page from the late activist Fran Peavey and sit in a park or two with a sign that says, “American willing to talk about race.” Throughout the journey, I’ll document what I hear and share it with you on my MoralesWrites blog.

I’m a long-time activist, writer, performer, and mom who lived in Milwaukee for nearly 25 years. I raised my children there, where they graduated from the public schools. I was an elected official, a Sunday School teacher, and a volunteer, working on issues of education, workers’ rights, women’s issues, LGBT rights, and environmental justice. In the roots of each of these struggles, I found race and racism tangled up. I want a better future for us and for our children.

What We Need & What You Get

To make this road trip happen, we need to borrow, rent, or buy a small RV (the Bookmobile!) that will allow us to travel cost-effectively, as well as buy gas, food, and supplies. I also need the services of a publicist and maybe a logistics assistant to make sure we cram in as many events as possible on this tour. And I’ll be writing and printing a discussion guide for book clubs, classes, and other groups to use on the tour and beyond. 

What you get are some great opportunities to be part of the journey without leaving home — and maybe get some help and inspiration for your own writing. 

The Impact

By publishing Meet Me Halfway, the University of Wisconsin Press has done something most publishers are afraid to do: publish a fiction book that faces race and racism head-on. Still, UWP is an academic press and it doesn’t have the big marketing departments and resources of the New York houses. 

By contributing to this tour, you will help get this risky book out there and let the publishing world know that the public wants more books that look honestly at race in America and challenge readers to make change. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise! Please share this campaign with others who care about addressing racism and working for a more just society. Share the Meet Me Halfway campaign through word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter, your blog, your listservs — anywhere. 

Please sign up for my email list on the MoralesWrites page so you can follow the book tour. 

And let me know if you think of a classroom, bookstore, book club or other organization I should visit as part of the tour. Thanks!

story:
“…very lovely, well considered…”

— Craig Mod, co-author of Koya Bound

“…[an] unusual winter journey…”

— John Ryle, Professor of Anthropology at Bard College

“…a ray of real experiences in a storm of fake influencers and vanity mongers.”

— Greg Takayama

Final update: The book is finished and available for sale

You can buy a copy of The Wilds of Shikoku here. The price is $45. It includes a physical copy of the book and a free download of the PDF Edition. 

Update + stretch goal

With three days to go we’ve hit 100%. Thank you all for making what is among my wildest of dreams a little less inchoate.

Stretch goal: Hit $12,000 and I will take a DJI Spark drone for aerial footage of the journey.

Introduction

Last year, I walked 4,300 kilometers along the back roads of Japan’s four main islands: Kyushu, Shikoku, Honshu, and Hokkaido. I crossed the mountainous interior of Shikoku in May 2017. It took only two weeks but it was the most interesting part of my 18-week journey across Japan. On the penultimate day, I walked through a village where nine out of ten houses were in ruins — but you could still get a cold Coke from a vending machine and walk on a perfectly surfaced road, while jetliners overhead were extending their landing gear on their approach to Osaka, one of the supercities of the world. On Shikoku, I found the melancholy future of the developed world.

Now I want to go back so I can show you. If this campaign is successful, you will be able to follow online as I walk across the wilds of Shikoku in the dead of winter, then, after I’ve made it across, read my printed field report.

Sketch of my proposed route across Shikoku

Shikoku is the smallest of Japan’s four main islands. It wasn’t until 30 years ago that one could reach it by road or rail. It is best known for the Shikoku Henro, where Buddhist pilgrims dressed in white circumambulate the island to visit 88 of its temples. On my walk, I will not follow the pilgrims’ path, but the roads of the island’s sparsely populated interior, from Shikoku’s easternmost point to its westernmost.

The Wilds of Shikoku will be the story of the price we pay to live in comfort. Cities everywhere are growing and the countryside is fading away, while we celebrate the handcrafted beauty of country life from the comforts of our city homes. Shikoku makes this story more visible than any other place I know. If you live anywhere in the developed world, it is probably your story, too. I know it is mine.

With your help, we can turn this story into a printed, tangible artifact, and also offer some very special perks.

What We Need & What You Get

Apart from the costs of pre-production, which we have already covered, The Wilds of Shikoku will have five main expenses:

  1. Getting to Japan (airfare, insurance, train tickets)
  2. Equipment (electronics, winter gear)
  3. Walking across Shikoku (food, bathhouse fees, data cards)
  4. Our collaborators’ fees
  5. Production and printing costs for the Field Report

We are pricing the campaign for the break-even point. Stay tuned for stretch goals if we go beyond our goal!

If the campaign is successfully funded, I will go to Japan in January 2019 and walk across Shikoku in late January to early February. If you contribute, and the campaign is a success, you will get:

1. THE FIELD REPORT

The ultimate aim of this journey is to produce a beautifully crafted and printed Field Report about what I saw on my 500-kilometer walk across some of the most remote parts of Japan in the dead of winter.

32 A3-sized pages of 105 g/m^2 cream-colored Awagami from Tokushima, Japan, our target for the Field Report. It feels substantial to hold.

The specifics:

  • It’s big: 32 A3-sized pages (29.7 × 42 cm / 11.69" × 16.53"), printed on 105 g/m^2, off-white German or Japanese paper, weighing in total 210 grams (0.46 pounds)
  • Featuring a hand-painted watercolor map of Shikoku by British illustrator Alice Cleary
  • Between 10,000–15,000 words (the length of a very long magazine article)
  • Dozens of original photographs by the author
  • Altitude and distance profile charts

Patrons of the Digital Pack will receive the Field Report in PDF format, printable at either A4 or US Letter size.

The Field Report will be written and produced after I complete the walk. Based on the conversations we’ve had with our graphic designer and our printer, it will be done by the end of April 2019. We aim to have them in the mail by May 1, 2019 (incidentally, the first day of Japan’s next imperial era).

2. REAL TIME BROADCAST

From my first steps leaving Cape Gamouda, Shikoku’s easternmost point, until I reach Cape Sada, its westernmost, you will be able to follow my walk online, in close to real time. What will you see? Apart from the staggering beauty of the land, I have no idea.

Sunset over Tosa-cho, Kochi Prefecture, Shikoku, on May 14, 2017
the ninth day of my walk across the island

But last year, when I walked across Shikoku, I met, among others, a French carpenter restoring an old Japanese house in the mountains, a Columbia University PhD from Tokyo who was employed by a village to re-design its education system, a naked man who asked me if I was from the Austro-Hungarian Empire, a beekeeper with a sniper rifle employed to cull the deer which threaten to overrun the rice fields, a Hungarian world champion kayaker teaching junior high school in a mountain village, and an agricultural engineer who happens to be the highest-ranked swordsman in Eastern Shikoku. I will re-visit some of these people and will in all likelihood meet others just as interesting. Such is the nature of long-distance walking.

Roadside statues on the Sadamisaki Peninsula, Ehime Prefecture, Shikoku, on May 6, 2017

I will carry two cameras and an iPhone, and post several times a day to Instagram and YouTube. The broadcast will be freely available for everyone, and archived on The Wilds of Shikoku website (to be launched in Summer 2019). For examples of similar broadcasts from my other journeys, see The Roads from Sata (my 4,300-kilometer walk across Japan in 2017) and Autocracy Holidays (an 8,000-kilometer road trip from Kazakhstan across Xinjiang, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, and Iran to Iraqi Kurdistan, in 2018).

3. LIMITED EDITION MAP PRINTS

The centerpiece of the Field Report will be a hand-painted watercolor map of Shikoku by the London-based illustrator Alice Cleary. She has already sketched it out and will paint it when the campaign is successfully funded. Alice works for print magazines and you may have come across her paintings and maps in Delicious Magazine, Delicious Australia, Great British Food, and Veggie Magazine.

This is not the final map, just a sketch on Alice’s worktable

We will be offering limited edition art prints of the map. Alice will paint the original at A3 (29.7 × 42 cm / 11.69" × 16.53"). Our prints, mounted on thick cardboard, will be at the same size. They will stand on their own and will also be suitable for framing.

Unlike the Field Report, which will be for sale on The Wilds of Shikoku website after the campaign is over, the prints will only be available for the duration of our campaign. If you want one, make a pledge by December 24, 2018.

4. ARTISANAL INDIGO TENUGUI, MADE ON SHIKOKU

The prefecture of Tokushima in Shikoku has been for centuries the center of Japanese indigo production: the plant-based fermented dye responsible for the magnificent color also referred to as Japan Blue. After the country opened to the West in the 19th century, the indigo industry was decimated by synthetic dyes. It is now experiencing a quiet comeback, and Hanga Yoshihara-Horvath, a Hungarian-Japanese artist, is one of the figures in the center of this revival.

Photo by Kyoko Nishimoto

Hanga, a classically trained textile artist, has lived in Tokushima for a decade with her husband, the indigo researcher Hitoshi Yoshihara, and their son Mihály Aoi. Her indigo work combines the Japanese techniques of sashiko (decorative stitching) and shibori (resist dyeing) with traditional Hungarian patterns and motifs.

Hanga will design and dye original tenugui — traditional Japanese cotton towels — for the supporters of The Wilds of Shikoku. They will be approximately 35×90 centimeters in size. Tenugui can be used for practically any purpose that calls for a piece of cloth: you can tie it around your forehead on a hot day, wrap stuff in it, use it in the bath as a washcloth, and so on. Artisanal handmade tenugui, like the ones Hanga will make, can also be hung and displayed. You can read more about tenugui in this article on Tofugu.

​Photo by Kyoko Nishimoto

We will limit the number of tenugui Hanga makes to the number of days it will take me to walk across Shikoku. We are offering 10 pieces for sale during the campaign.

5. ALAN BOOTH’S ESSAY COLLECTION, SIGNED BY EDITOR TIMOTHY HARRIS

If you’re reading this, you probably need no introduction to Alan Booth. He is the late author of The Roads to Sata, the famous travel book about his walk across three of Japan’s four main islands. Several years later, he traveled to the fourth, Shikoku, to walk across its mountainous interior. Until a few months ago, you had to have been on a Japan Airlines flight in early 1985 to have read the account of his walk, because it was published by WINDS, the airline’s in-flight magazine.

Alan Booth (right) with Timothy Harris, both looking very theatrical. Photo by Stuart Varnam-Atkin

But Timothy Harris, Booth’s close friend and editor, recently put together an anthology of Booth’s uncollected writings, This Great Stage of Fools, which includes the account of Booth’s walk across Shikoku, titled Roads Out of Time.

Tim has graciously offered to sign copies of the anthology for supporters of this campaign. Here is an excerpt from his introduction to Roads Out of Time:

He decided to [walk across Shikoku] along the island’s longest axis: east to west — a five-hundred-kilometer walk. The walk was, of course, accomplished in a fraction of the time the longer journey took — eighteen days as opposed to four months — but, day for day, it was at least as hard, since Alan had chosen to walk not along the coast, but through the mountains and hills of the island’s interior — country as remote and rugged as any in Japan.

I had not known of Booth’s walk across Shikoku when I walked across the island in 2017, but we crossed the island on very similar paths (more on this if you read on). In memory of his life and his work, the walk I plan to complete for The Wilds of Shikoku will follow in his footsteps exactly, as far as they can be reconstructed from his account.

6. A PRIVATE PRESENTATION OF MY WALK

In every journey there are stories that don’t make it into any Field Report. Stories too extraordinary to be believable, too personal to print, too ephemeral to publish. These are some of the best stories. You have them, too. After the Field Report is printed and mailed, I will tell the story behind the story of The Wilds of Shikoku. This will be in the form of a 60-minute presentation, with unpublished pictures, followed by free-form conversation. The ideal setting for this would be a small group eager for strangeness and adventure: your institute, your startup, your school.

This rewards is limited to 2 backers. You can choose any location in the world (the cost does not include me getting there).

7. A PRIVATE WALK ACROSS SHIKOKU

I have the feeling that I can write on these enormous partitions, of 3,000 or 4,000 meters high, as a professor writes on a blackboard with a chalk. But I don’t only make that to write these lines, these imaginary lines, I live these lines. I also have the impression that after, these lines remain there, even though I am the only one that can feel them, see them, that I live them and nobody else will ever be able to see them, but they are there and they will remain forever there.

— Reinhold Messner, in Werner Herzog’s The Dark Glow of the Mountains

The world is a palimpsest of imaginary lines and we all walk in the footsteps of others. Alan Booth once followed the steps of Saigo Takamori, the brooding 19th-century samurai with a dog named Tsun, and last year I unwittingly retraced the footsteps of Alan Booth across Shikoku.

Works of art about travel and walking have exerted a disproportionate influence on my imagination, and I have often felt their authors loom large in my life. For this campaign I’m offering something I have never been able to do myself: to experience a work with its author in its original setting.

For one supporter of The Wilds of Shikoku, I’m offering the chance to re-walk the exact path of my walk. We will go together, at a time of your choice, across this beautiful and haunted island, in the footsteps of Alan Booth, myself, and countless others, to which we will add our own, and nobody else will ever be able to see them, but they will be there, and they will remain forever there.

About Peter

Photo by Kyoko Nishimoto

Peter Orosz is a peripatetic writer and photographer. In 2017, he walked 4,300 kilometers across Japan from the south of Kyushu to the east of Hokkaido. A year before, he walked 850 kilometers across the Zagros Mountains from Hamadan, Iran to Erbil, Iraq. Back when he wasn’t walking, he wrote for Roads & Kingdoms, Wired, Jalopnik, and other websites, and served as an editorial manager at Gawker Media.

Why Walk in Winter?

In May 2017, on my walk across Shikoku, I had breakfast with Ayano Tsukimi, a lady who lives in a mountain village named Nagoro. She served me a simple Japanese breakfast of miso soup, braised potatoes, and mountain vegetables she had picked herself. She is the creator of an art project about the depopulation of her village, where she makes a life-sized cloth doll for every villager who moves away or dies. Her dolls now vastly outnumber the humans in Nagoro. Her life and her work were the focus of Valley of Dolls, a short documentary film by the German journalist Fritz Schumann.

Ayano Tsukimi chilling in front of her house on May 17, 2017

On that beautiful spring day, it was hard to see the harshness of life in Nagoro. But after breakfast, Ms. Tsukimi showed me pictures of her life in winter. On this gentle subtropical island, known for its temples and tangerines, she stood waist-deep in the snow in front of her old wooden house, which was heated by a single charcoal burner and connected to the outside world across a mile-high pass in the mountains. Barely more than 200 kilometers away, across that pass and two great bridges, lay Osaka, one of the world’s biggest cities. Its canyons of glass and steel could have been another planet, one vastly more massive than little Nagoro, with an irresistible gravity.

Here was the star of a film seen by more than 500,000 people, living in a country which loses the same number of people every year. Her spacious wooden house is a thing of handcrafted beauty. Wildflowers drop into the cold spring water of her drink cooler, and she breathes the pure mountain air. Her aesthetically pleasing life is also unimaginably hard, and it’s a lifestyle that doesn’t survive contact with the big city. The quiet forests and the verdant mountains don’t stand a chance against the siren song of 24/7 convenience stores and central heating, and this contrast is brought into sharp focus in the winter, when nature is at its cruelest, and the life to be lived there has very little to do with how we imagine life in the developed world.

The schoolhouse of Nagoro, Tokushima Prefecture, Shikoku, on May 17, 2017

The sort of country life we find beautiful only exists until the people who live it have no choice. Once they do, they leave it behind. No young professional will move back to a place like Nagoro from Osaka. And couples with young children definitely won’t: the village school is closed, and the bridge across the river which leads to it lies unrepaired, guarded by two of Ms. Tsukimi’s dolls.

Whatever I will experience on my walk will never approach the hardness of daily life in a village. But maybe, over weeks of walking, there will be moments when I will be able to see it, so I can write about it truthfully. About how we shed our beautiful clothes, how we leave our beautiful houses, how we stop making our delicious food, how we may lose our language, and how, in return, we get a comfortable life. And once we’re comfortable, we realize what we had lost. This is what I want to show you in The Wilds of Shikoku.

Why Follow Alan Booth’s Path?

In the summer and autumn of 1977, the British writer Alan Booth walked the length of Japan from the northernmost cape of Hokkaido to the southernmost cape of Kyushu. A few years later, he wrote an account of his journey, The Roads to Sata, which became one of the classics of 20th century travel writing.

It was one of the books which inspired my own walk across Japan, so much so that I titled my field notes from the journey The Roads from Sata. I had set out, in April 2017, to retrace his steps, but the gravity of the mountains pulled me into Japan’s interior. Our paths barely crossed and our walks differed in almost every way. While Booth walked from north to south, followed the coastline when possible, avoided the mountains, and slept in country inns, I walked from south to east, traversed as many mountains as possible, and slept in shacks, shrines, and under the stars. But the main difference was that he never set foot on Shikoku.

On my way home, in August 2017, I stopped in Tokyo to meet Timothy Harris, Alan Booth’s old friend and editor (Booth himself passed away in 1993). Over a couple of excellent beers in Shinjuku, Tim mentioned that in 1983, six years after his walk across Japan, Alan went back to Shikoku and walked across it as well — following not the pilgrims’ path but in a straight line across the island’s mountainous interior. And so, unwittingly, I retraced his steps in the very place where I had thought there were no steps of his to be retraced.

Roads Out of Time, Alan’s account of his walk across Shikoku, was published in February 1985 by WINDS, the in-flight magazine of Japan Airlines. At our meeting Tim told me that he was working on an anthology of Alan’s unpublished writings, which would include the story of his Shikoku walk. The anthology, titled This Great Stage of Fools, was published earlier this year by Bright Wave Media. When I received my copy, I was astonished to read that he had walked on many of the same roads as I had, in many cases across the same villages, making very similar observations along the way.

That’s when I decided that I would go back to Shikoku. To follow in Alan’s footsteps and to retrace mine, to treat his account as a screenplay to be staged, to try to see with his eyes what became of the wilds of Shikoku 36 years later.

Risks & Challenges

I have been walking alone for years and have covered over 6,000 kilometers in the past three years on walks ranging from three days to four months, in Croatia, Iran, Iraq, Hungary, Japan, and Serbia. I walk with a 10-kilogram rucksack and sleep where I fancy. I have been writing and taking photographs for an audience for 15 years. The Wilds of Shikoku builds on these skills.

The author in Higashinaruse, Akita Prefecture, on the 92nd day of his walk across Japan. Photo by Tadashi Honma.

The Walk

Low-to-medium risk. I’m in good physical condition for my 38 years, with no known medical issues. I have a good set of gear that I would trust my life to. I have walked in temperatures ranging from –15 °C to +45 °C, from sea level to above 4,000 meters. With my pack, I can comfortably cover 40 kilometers with 1,000 meters of elevation gain in a day, 55 with 2,000 if I have to push it. I would say low risk, period, but in Japan the weather can get interesting, particularly in the mountains in January.

The Field Report

Low risk. We have a graphic design team in place, and a printer we’ve worked with for 20 years. Once I have the report written and proofed, they will get to work.

The Online Broadcast

Low risk. I may be going into the mountains, but this is still Japan: if my phone breaks I can replace it within a day, and these days you need nothing else to broadcast.

The Map

Low risk. Alice painted the sketch you see in a day. Imagine what she’ll be able to do when she has a full week at her disposal.

The Tenugui

Low risk. Hanga is a proper Japanese artisan who has been doing this for 20+ years. She has a vat of fermented indigo dye in her own bathroom, just in case.

The Alan Booth Book

Low risk. The books are printed, and they’re warehoused in Tokyo, where Timothy Harris will sign them and the publisher will ship them out from.

The Private Presentation

Low risk. One cannot walk 500 kilometers and leave without very interesting stories.

The Private Walk

Low-to-medium risk. You can do this with zero preparation. If you don’t believe me, ask my brother, who flew out of his office last year to join me for the last 1,000 kilometers of my walk across Japan. But there is always the weather. See above. Also, the spirits: You have to be on good terms with them.

Media

  • Boing Boing: Crowdfund campaign for a 500-kilometer walk across rural Japan
  • Index: Csak egy könnyed séta a senkiföldjén (in Hungarian)

Credits and thanks

In memory of Alan Booth

  • Production, cover design, ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️: Natalie Kallay
  • Cover photo: Marton Novak
  • Map: Alice Cleary
  • Video: Róbert Iván
  • Music: Thy Catafalque
  • Footage: Takuya Ishikawa
  • Photos of Hanga and the author: Kyoko Nishimoto

Additional thanks to Gábor Bazsó, Ry Beville, John Ebert, Timothy Harris, Hanga Yoshihara-Horvath, Gábor Tálos and Ágnes Irina Vigh, and the hundreds of strangers who helped me on my walks, expecting nothing in return.

Best wishes,

Peter

Cities everywhere are growing and the countryside is fading away, while we celebrate the handcrafted beauty of country life from the comforts of our city homes. Shikoku makes this story more visible than any other place I know. If you live anywhere in the developed world, it is probably your story, too. I know it is mine.With your help, we can turn this story into a printed, tangible artifact, and also offer some very special perks.What We Need & What You GetApart from the costs of pre-production, which we have already covered, The Wilds of Shikoku will have five main expenses:
Getting to Japan (airfare, insurance, train tickets)
Equipment (electronics, winter gear)
Walking across Shikoku (food, bathhouse fees, data cards)
Our collaborators’ fees
Production and printing costs for the Field Report
We are pricing the campaign for the break-even point. Stay tuned for stretch goals if we go beyond our goal!If the campaign is successfully funded, I will go to Japan in January 2019 and walk across Shikoku in late January to early February. If you contribute, and the campaign is a success, you will get:1. THE FIELD REPORTThe ultimate aim of this journey is to produce a beautifully crafted and printed Field Report about what I saw on my 500-kilometer walk across some of the most remote parts of Japan in the dead of winter.32 A3-sized pages of 105 g/m^2 cream-colored Awagami from Tokushima, Japan, our target for the Field Report. It feels substantial to hold.The specifics:
It’s big: 32 A3-sized pages (29.7 × 42 cm / 11.69" × 16.53"), printed on 105 g/m^2, off-white German or Japanese paper, weighing in total 210 grams (0.46 pounds)
Featuring a hand-painted watercolor map of Shikoku by British illustrator Alice Cleary
Between 10,000–15,000 words (the length of a very long magazine article)
Dozens of original photographs by the author
Altitude and distance profile charts
Patrons of the Digital Pack will receive the Field Report in PDF format, printable at either A4 or US Letter size.The Field Report will be written and produced after I complete the walk. Based on the conversations we’ve had with our graphic designer and our printer, it will be done by the end of April 2019. We aim to have them in the mail by May 1, 2019 (incidentally, the first day of Japan’s next imperial era).2. REAL TIME BROADCASTFrom my first steps leaving Cape Gamouda, Shikoku’s easternmost point, until I reach Cape Sada, its westernmost, you will be able to follow my walk online, in close to real time. What will you see? Apart from the staggering beauty of the land, I have no idea.Sunset over Tosa-cho, Kochi Prefecture, Shikoku, on May 14, 2017the ninth day of my walk across the islandBut last year, when I walked across Shikoku, I met, among others, a French carpenter restoring an old Japanese house in the mountains, a Columbia University PhD from Tokyo who was employed by a village to re-design its education system, a naked man who asked me if I was from the Austro-Hungarian Empire, a beekeeper with a sniper rifle employed to cull the deer which threaten to overrun the rice fields, a Hungarian world champion kayaker teaching junior high school in a mountain village, and an agricultural engineer who happens to be the highest-ranked swordsman in Eastern Shikoku. I will re-visit some of these people and will in all likelihood meet others just as interesting. Such is the nature of long-distance walking.Roadside statues on the Sadamisaki Peninsula, Ehime Prefecture, Shikoku, on May 6, 2017I will carry two cameras and an iPhone, and post several times a day to Instagram and YouTube. The broadcast will be freely available for everyone, and archived on The Wilds of Shikoku website (to be launched in Summer 2019). For examples of similar broadcasts from my other journeys, see The Roads from Sata (my 4,300-kilometer walk across Japan in 2017) and Autocracy Holidays (an 8,000-kilometer road trip from Kazakhstan across Xinjiang, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, and Iran to Iraqi Kurdistan, in 2018).3. LIMITED EDITION MAP PRINTSThe centerpiece of the Field Report will be a hand-painted watercolor map of Shikoku by the London-based illustrator Alice Cleary. She has already sketched it out and will paint it when the campaign is successfully funded. Alice works for print magazines and you may have come across her paintings and maps in Delicious Magazine, Delicious Australia, Great British Food, and Veggie Magazine.This is not the final map, just a sketch on Alice’s worktableWe will be offering limited edition art prints of the map. Alice will paint the original at A3 (29.7 × 42 cm / 11.69" × 16.53"). Our prints, mounted on thick cardboard, will be at the same size. They will stand on their own and will also be suitable for framing.Unlike the Field Report, which will be for sale on The Wilds of Shikoku website after the campaign is over, the prints will only be available for the duration of our campaign. If you want one, make a pledge by December 24, 2018.4. ARTISANAL INDIGO TENUGUI, MADE ON SHIKOKUThe prefecture of Tokushima in Shikoku has been for centuries the center of Japanese indigo production: the plant-based fermented dye responsible for the magnificent color also referred to as Japan Blue. After the country opened to the West in the 19th century, the indigo industry was decimated by synthetic dyes. It is now experiencing a quiet comeback, and Hanga Yoshihara-Horvath, a Hungarian-Japanese artist, is one of the figures in the center of this revival.Photo by Kyoko NishimotoHanga, a classically trained textile artist, has lived in Tokushima for a decade with her husband, the indigo researcher Hitoshi Yoshihara, and their son Mihály Aoi. Her indigo work combines the Japanese techniques of sashiko (decorative stitching) and shibori (resist dyeing) with traditional Hungarian patterns and motifs.Hanga will design and dye original tenugui — traditional Japanese cotton towels — for the supporters of The Wilds of Shikoku. They will be approximately 35×90 centimeters in size. Tenugui can be used for practically any purpose that calls for a piece of cloth: you can tie it around your forehead on a hot day, wrap stuff in it, use it in the bath as a washcloth, and so on. Artisanal handmade tenugui, like the ones Hanga will make, can also be hung and displayed. You can read more about tenugui in this article on Tofugu.​Photo by Kyoko NishimotoWe will limit the number of tenugui Hanga makes to the number of days it will take me to walk across Shikoku. We are offering 10 pieces for sale during the campaign.5. ALAN BOOTH’S ESSAY COLLECTION, SIGNED BY EDITOR TIMOTHY HARRISIf you’re reading this, you probably need no introduction to Alan Booth. He is the late author of The Roads to Sata, the famous travel book about his walk across three of Japan’s four main islands. Several years later, he traveled to the fourth, Shikoku, to walk across its mountainous interior. Until a few months ago, you had to have been on a Japan Airlines flight in early 1985 to have read the account of his walk, because it was published by WINDS, the airline’s in-flight magazine.Alan Booth (right) with Timothy Harris, both looking very theatrical. Photo by Stuart Varnam-AtkinBut Timothy Harris, Booth’s close friend and editor, recently put together an anthology of Booth’s uncollected writings, This Great Stage of Fools, which includes the account of Booth’s walk across Shikoku, titled Roads Out of Time.Tim has graciously offered to sign copies of the anthology for supporters of this campaign. Here is an excerpt from his introduction to Roads Out of Time:He decided to [walk across Shikoku] along the island’s longest axis: east to west — a five-hundred-kilometer walk. The walk was, of course, accomplished in a fraction of the time the longer journey took — eighteen days as opposed to four months — but, day for day, it was at least as hard, since Alan had chosen to walk not along the coast, but through the mountains and hills of the island’s interior — country as remote and rugged as any in Japan.I had not known of Booth’s walk across Shikoku when I walked across the island in 2017, but we crossed the island on very similar paths (more on this if you read on). In memory of his life and his work, the walk I plan to complete for The Wilds of Shikoku will follow in his footsteps exactly, as far as they can be reconstructed from his account.6. A PRIVATE PRESENTATION OF MY WALKIn every journey there are stories that don’t make it into any Field Report. Stories too extraordinary to be believable, too personal to print, too ephemeral to publish. These are some of the best stories. You have them, too. After the Field Report is printed and mailed, I will tell the story behind the story of The Wilds of Shikoku. This will be in the form of a 60-minute presentation, with unpublished pictures, followed by free-form conversation. The ideal setting for this would be a small group eager for strangeness and adventure: your institute, your startup, your school.This rewards is limited to 2 backers. You can choose any location in the world (the cost does not include me getting there).7. A PRIVATE WALK ACROSS SHIKOKU
I have the feeling that I can write on these enormous partitions, of 3,000 or 4,000 meters high, as a professor writes on a blackboard with a chalk. But I don’t only make that to write these lines, these imaginary lines, I live these lines. I also have the impression that after, these lines remain there, even though I am the only one that can feel them, see them, that I live them and nobody else will ever be able to see them, but they are there and they will remain forever there.
— Reinhold Messner, in Werner Herzog’s The Dark Glow of the Mountains
The world is a palimpsest of imaginary lines and we all walk in the footsteps of others. Alan Booth once followed the steps of Saigo Takamori, the brooding 19th-century samurai with a dog named Tsun, and last year I unwittingly retraced the footsteps of Alan Booth across Shikoku.Works of art about travel and walking have exerted a disproportionate influence on my imagination, and I have often felt their authors loom large in my life. For this campaign I’m offering something I have never been able to do myself: to experience a work with its author in its original setting.For one supporter of The Wilds of Shikoku, I’m offering the chance to re-walk the exact path of my walk. We will go together, at a time of your choice, across this beautiful and haunted island, in the footsteps of Alan Booth, myself, and countless others, to which we will add our own, and nobody else will ever be able to see them, but they will be there, and they will remain forever there.About PeterPhoto by Kyoko NishimotoPeter Orosz is a peripatetic writer and photographer. In 2017, he walked 4,300 kilometers across Japan from the south of Kyushu to the east of Hokkaido. A year before, he walked 850 kilometers across the Zagros Mountains from Hamadan, Iran to Erbil, Iraq. Back when he wasn’t walking, he wrote for Roads & Kingdoms, Wired, Jalopnik, and other websites, and served as an editorial manager at Gawker Media.Why Walk in Winter?In May 2017, on my walk across Shikoku, I had breakfast with Ayano Tsukimi, a lady who lives in a mountain village named Nagoro. She served me a simple Japanese breakfast of miso soup, braised potatoes, and mountain vegetables she had picked herself. She is the creator of an art project about the depopulation of her village, where she makes a life-sized cloth doll for every villager who moves away or dies. Her dolls now vastly outnumber the humans in Nagoro. Her life and her work were the focus of Valley of Dolls, a short documentary film by the German journalist Fritz Schumann.Ayano Tsukimi chilling in front of her house on May 17, 2017On that beautiful spring day, it was hard to see the harshness of life in Nagoro. But after breakfast, Ms. Tsukimi showed me pictures of her life in winter. On this gentle subtropical island, known for its temples and tangerines, she stood waist-deep in the snow in front of her old wooden house, which was heated by a single charcoal burner and connected to the outside world across a mile-high pass in the mountains. Barely more than 200 kilometers away, across that pass and two great bridges, lay Osaka, one of the world’s biggest cities. Its canyons of glass and steel could have been another planet, one vastly more massive than little Nagoro, with an irresistible gravity.Here was the star of a film seen by more than 500,000 people, living in a country which loses the same number of people every year. Her spacious wooden house is a thing of handcrafted beauty. Wildflowers drop into the cold spring water of her drink cooler, and she breathes the pure mountain air. Her aesthetically pleasing life is also unimaginably hard, and it’s a lifestyle that doesn’t survive contact with the big city. The quiet forests and the verdant mountains don’t stand a chance against the siren song of 24/7 convenience stores and central heating, and this contrast is brought into sharp focus in the winter, when nature is at its cruelest, and the life to be lived there has very little to do with how we imagine life in the developed world.The schoolhouse of Nagoro, Tokushima Prefecture, Shikoku, on May 17, 2017The sort of country life we find beautiful only exists until the people who live it have no choice. Once they do, they leave it behind. No young professional will move back to a place like Nagoro from Osaka. And couples with young children definitely won’t: the village school is closed, and the bridge across the river which leads to it lies unrepaired, guarded by two of Ms. Tsukimi’s dolls.Whatever I will experience on my walk will never approach the hardness of daily life in a village. But maybe, over weeks of walking, there will be moments when I will be able to see it, so I can write about it truthfully. About how we shed our beautiful clothes, how we leave our beautiful houses, how we stop making our delicious food, how we may lose our language, and how, in return, we get a comfortable life. And once we’re comfortable, we realize what we had lost. This is what I want to show you in The Wilds of Shikoku.Why Follow Alan Booth’s Path?In the summer and autumn of 1977, the British writer Alan Booth walked the length of Japan from the northernmost cape of Hokkaido to the southernmost cape of Kyushu. A few years later, he wrote an account of his journey, The Roads to Sata, which became one of the classics of 20th century travel writing.It was one of the books which inspired my own walk across Japan, so much so that I titled my field notes from the journey The Roads from Sata. I had set out, in April 2017, to retrace his steps, but the gravity of the mountains pulled me into Japan’s interior. Our paths barely crossed and our walks differed in almost every way. While Booth walked from north to south, followed the coastline when possible, avoided the mountains, and slept in country inns, I walked from south to east, traversed as many mountains as possible, and slept in shacks, shrines, and under the stars. But the main difference was that he never set foot on Shikoku.On my way home, in August 2017, I stopped in Tokyo to meet Timothy Harris, Alan Booth’s old friend and editor (Booth himself passed away in 1993). Over a couple of excellent beers in Shinjuku, Tim mentioned that in 1983, six years after his walk across Japan, Alan went back to Shikoku and walked across it as well — following not the pilgrims’ path but in a straight line across the island’s mountainous interior. And so, unwittingly, I retraced his steps in the very place where I had thought there were no steps of his to be retraced.Roads Out of Time, Alan’s account of his walk across Shikoku, was published in February 1985 by WINDS, the in-flight magazine of Japan Airlines. At our meeting Tim told me that he was working on an anthology of Alan’s unpublished writings, which would include the story of his Shikoku walk. The anthology, titled This Great Stage of Fools, was published earlier this year by Bright Wave Media. When I received my copy, I was astonished to read that he had walked on many of the same roads as I had, in many cases across the same villages, making very similar observations along the way.That’s when I decided that I would go back to Shikoku. To follow in Alan’s footsteps and to retrace mine, to treat his account as a screenplay to be staged, to try to see with his eyes what became of the wilds of Shikoku 36 years later.Risks & ChallengesI have been walking alone for years and have covered over 6,000 kilometers in the past three years on walks ranging from three days to four months, in Croatia, Iran, Iraq, Hungary, Japan, and Serbia. I walk with a 10-kilogram rucksack and sleep where I fancy. I have been writing and taking photographs for an audience for 15 years. The Wilds of Shikoku builds on these skills.The author in Higashinaruse, Akita Prefecture, on the 92nd day of his walk across Japan. Photo by Tadashi Honma.The WalkLow-to-medium risk. I’m in good physical condition for my 38 years, with no known medical issues. I have a good set of gear that I would trust my life to. I have walked in temperatures ranging from –15 °C to +45 °C, from sea level to above 4,000 meters. With my pack, I can comfortably cover 40 kilometers with 1,000 meters of elevation gain in a day, 55 with 2,000 if I have to push it. I would say low risk, period, but in Japan the weather can get interesting, particularly in the mountains in January.The Field ReportLow risk. We have a graphic design team in place, and a printer we’ve worked with for 20 years. Once I have the report written and proofed, they will get to work.The Online BroadcastLow risk. I may be going into the mountains, but this is still Japan: if my phone breaks I can replace it within a day, and these days you need nothing else to broadcast.The MapLow risk. Alice painted the sketch you see in a day. Imagine what she’ll be able to do when she has a full week at her disposal.The TenuguiLow risk. Hanga is a proper Japanese artisan who has been doing this for 20+ years. She has a vat of fermented indigo dye in her own bathroom, just in case.The Alan Booth BookLow risk. The books are printed, and they’re warehoused in Tokyo, where Timothy Harris will sign them and the publisher will ship them out from.The Private PresentationLow risk. One cannot walk 500 kilometers and leave without very interesting stories.The Private WalkLow-to-medium risk. You can do this with zero preparation. If you don’t believe me, ask my brother, who flew out of his office last year to join me for the last 1,000 kilometers of my walk across Japan. But there is always the weather. See above. Also, the spirits: You have to be on good terms with them.Media
Boing Boing: Crowdfund campaign for a 500-kilometer walk across rural Japan

Index: Csak egy könnyed séta a senkiföldjén (in Hungarian)
Credits and thanksIn memory of Alan Booth
Production, cover design, ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️: Natalie Kallay

Cover photo: Marton Novak

Map: Alice Cleary

Video: Róbert Iván
Music: Thy Catafalque

Footage: Takuya Ishikawa
Photos of Hanga and the author: Kyoko Nishimoto

Additional thanks to Gábor Bazsó, Ry Beville, John Ebert, Timothy Harris, Hanga Yoshihara-Horvath, Gábor Tálos and Ágnes Irina Vigh, and the hundreds of strangers who helped me on my walks, expecting nothing in return.Best wishes,Peter

CAMPAIGN UPDATE: Thanks to an incredible community of 150 supporters (backers and people who made donations), I have exceeded my $8,000 fundraising goal. I look forward to building community with all of my campaign supporters in the months to come!

Story of My Book

My name is Charisse M. Williams and I am the author of Thriving While Black. This book was inspired by my experience of thriving in one of the most challenging years I have lived--2020. I was curious about how other Black folks were thriving and what was enabling it, so I decided to find out. 

Thriving While Black is about the intersection of race and wellbeing in America. It focuses on twelve themes that contribute to thriving including purpose, self-love, community and hope.

Part memoir, part guide, Thriving While Black chronicles my experience navigating 2020. It also shares the stories from my interviews with a diverse group of over fifty extraordinary African Americans.

One of them is Angie O’Neal. A two-time breast cancer survivor, Angie completed her first marathon not long after going through chemotherapy for the second time. Inspired by family and with the support of her community, she accomplished something that years earlier was only in her dreams.

I also share the story of Ryan Wilson whose sense of purpose, nurtured from a very young age, led to the founding of The Gathering Spot, a membership club that serves as a hub for collaboration, connections and experiences, changing the way we build community.

Then there’s Adeola Whitney. The Coronavirus pandemic and gym closures inspired her to take daily long walks with her husband. Those walks improved their health, fortified their marriage and helped them make really important decisions for their family, including her pursuit of her role as CEO of a national nonprofit.

Finally, I share the story of Lama Rod Owens, Buddhist teacher, author and activist who earned his title of “Lama” meaning “teacher” through a mostly silent, three-year training. Lama Rod models how we can use self-love to transform ourselves and the world.

You will love this book if you enjoy reading inspiring stories about people leading extraordinary lives and making a profound impact on the world. You will also learn how we use the power of reframing to find hope, gratitude and opportunity in any situation, especially in 2020.

Thriving While Black includes questions for reflection and practices you can put into place that can help you thrive more. 

What I'm Asking & What You'll Get

Thriving While Black will be published with New Degree Press in April, 2021. Your support will help cover the costs of publishing. It will also help me build an audience for my book before it is published, which is critical to its long-term success. Money raised will go towards the following:

  • The editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in April, 2021.
  • The cover design of my book. (The mockups you see currently are a placeholder!)
  • The layout design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats).
  • The copy editing for my book to polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication.
  • The launch & promotion efforts for my book when I ultimately publish this in Spring of 2021.

When I pre-sell 120 copies of my book, I will be able to publish a paperback and ebook.

When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also be able publish a hardcover edition.

When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will be able to publish a hardcover edition and an audiobook.

I am offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now. Depending on the level of support:

  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish.
  • Your name will appear in the Acknowledgments section of my book.
  • You will receive early access to the Introduction and other excerpts from my book, with the opportunity to review them and give me early feedback.
  • You will have the opportunity to be involved in selecting my cover and title.
  • You will be invited to join my Author Community and get behind-the-scenes sneak peeks into the publishing process.
  • And much more!

About the Author

Charisse M. Williams is a full-time executive leadership coach and facilitator who helps individuals and teams achieve their goals and thrive. She is a passionate leader and entrepreneur who brings passion, insatiable curiosity, warmth and authenticity to all of her work.

The idea for her book, Thriving While Black, struck her when she was sitting in the sun on the front porch after one of her workouts. She found that as a brand new business owner, she was thriving in the midst of a global pandemic and too many killings of unarmed Black people to count. She was curious to unpack how she was thriving in the midst of all this and learn from the contributors in her book.

Becoming a full-time coach in January 2020 is an important part of her story and where the book begins. Her undergraduate degree in Africana Studies from Cornell University and Law Degree from Northwestern University helped solidify her passion for Black people and culture, equity and justice. Her love for yoga and meditation, travel, learning and the arts are all reflected in this book's journey. It is the integration of all of her talents, experiences and curiosities that help her thrive and she is excited to share it with the world in Thriving While Black.

For more information, you can visit her website at www.charissemwilliams.com, email her at hello@charissemwilliams.com, or connect on social media. LinkedIn: Charisse M. Williams, Instagram: @charisse_m_williams

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by including the cost of mailing and shipping the signed copies into each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we ship the pre-order rewards to you as early as possible. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as to when my book will publish. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #thrivingwhileblack and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so that we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my pre-sale campaign via Indiegogo at the top of the page.

Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it via text or direct message on social media.

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support! I literally could not do this without you.

Thanks again,

Charisse M. Williams

story:
Story of My Book

Mama Eats First is a book about the transition to motherhood and how to optimize the first forty days after birth to truly support the recovery and emergence of the newborn mom. 

My name is Elizabeth Schieffelin Liao and I am the author of Mama Eats First. I wrote this book because moms need more support than what our system and culture offer now. With the right tools and loving guidance, newborn moms can create an environment that allows for deep healing, recovery and a transition into a thriving, empowered experience. 

I was inspired to write this book because our country is in crisis. Newborn mothers are not being taken care of by the system at large, our culture, and many communities. We face many challenges including: 

  • Many moms hold the belief that asking for help is sign of weakness, failure or being a burden.
  • Shame, "mom guilt", and feelings of not being enough are felt by so many women. 
  • Abdominal pain, aches, even incontinence are considered par-for-the-course of motherhood. 
  • Women are being medicated at higher rates and report feeling less supported and more stressed than at any other point in history. 
  • The US is the only developed country with a rising maternal mortality rate.
  • Our culture tells new moms to “bounce back” instead of embracing and loving their new bodies. 
  • Millennial moms are bombarded with information from the internet, but often miss out on the wisdom of the women who came before. 
  • There is a belief that because motherhood is natural, it should somehow “just come naturally”. 
  • The majority of available resources on the postpartum period are focused on the baby and her/his needs, developmental milestones and features - NOT the mom and her healing/recovery.


Finally, in the West, we tend to spend most of their time and energy during pregnancy preparing for the birth; women often find themselves unprepared at best, and blindsided at worst, when they enter into the postpartum period.

But there is another path to motherhood - A path where we can experience a graceful and well supported transition to motherhood. I’ve lived it and I’ve spent the last year learning about how "Mother Centered" cultures create healing and empowering experiences for women. 

For the forty days after my birth as a new mother, I only had two priorities: to rest and recover, and to feed and care for my baby. We created systems so that my normal work and household responsibilities were delegated or paused. Every day, my mother-in-law made special broths, porridges, and teas with medicinal herbs and ingredients that promoted my physical recovery. I was kept warm and cocooned. I didn’t rush to “get my body back”. 

I emerged from my Forty Day window as a new mother feeling healthier, more whole, and more energized than I had felt ever in my life. My experience was a dire contrast to many American moms' warnings of depletion and exhaustion. And yet, my experience was not unique.

As I researched other "Mother Centered" cultures in parts of Sweden and India, Malaysia and Mexico, I learned that their own healing approaches to postpartum recovery share many of the same threads as my Forty Day recovery, known in Mandarin as zuo yuezi. This includes eating nourishing foods, prioritizing rest, connecting with women, working with ceremony and ritual, receiving healing touch.

In my book, I translate traditions from other cultures into practices and systems that are accessible to you now. Whether you have a whole village of aunties ready to help or are building your own team far from family or friends, I offer guidance on the what, how, and when. 

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover a new way of experiencing the initial Forty Days of your postpartum period. In this book, I hope to instill in you the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for motherhood and women’s health. Ultimately, for all expecting and new mamas, I want this book to empower you to ask for help, and for your communities to step up and provide the support that you deserve. 

In this book, you'll learn about crucial elements for how to recover using rest and nourishment and practical ways to work with traditional practices. You'll hear stories such as...

  • How eating to support your hormones can help you with healthy weight loss, energy balance, and breastfeeding.
  • The power of ceremony and ritual to support the transition to motherhood.
  • The healing power of self-compassion during uncertain or challenging times with a newborn baby and as a newborn mama.
  • The vastly different health and happiness outcomes that modern mamas experience when they try out simple "Mother Centered" practices.

You will love this book if you are undergoing your own transition to motherhood or are supporting a partner through it. You will also be interested if you are contemplating becoming a mama or have friends/family who are expecting. And anyone interested in cross cultural learning will find the practices offered to be fascinating.

Mama Eats First is a nonfiction book that speaks to mamas (expecting or current) and all people in their support system (family, friends, as well as doulas, coaches, and medical professionals) who want to look at the recovery process and initiation into motherhood in a new way.

 

The Book - Mama Eats First

At present, the book is written in six parts.

Part 1 contains the introduction + chapters 1-3. In this section, you will learn about the unique challenges and opportunities facing millennial moms today. You will also learn about the groundbreaking concept of “Matresence”, the time period when a woman experiences more neurobiological changes than at any other point in her life. Through this lens, we explore how to reframe the entry point of motherhood in a way that better serves the women going through the portal. Finally, you will learn about some postpartum realities, so you’re not left scratching your head and wondering if what you’re feeling is ‘normal’. Think of this as a mother-focused version of What to Expect. 

Part 2 contains chapters 4-7. Do you have trouble asking for or receiving help? This section will completely transform the way you think about asking for and receiving help. You will learn why behavioral psychologist Adam Grant sees receiving help as an ultimate form of giving. You will also read stories of how women with vastly different life circumstances approached building their villages. Whether you have a strong local community or feel like you’re on your own, you will discover strategies for getting the help you need. 

Part 3 contains chapters 8-12. Put on your comfiest robe and snuggle up as you enjoy this restorative section focused on the ultimate need of every new mom: rest! You will read about my personal struggle with being okay with slowing down, and how I hacked rest with a crying newborn (it was simple but not easy). Learn from sleep experts about feeling recharged and what to do when it simply isn’t possible to lie down.

Part 4 contains chapters 13-19. This section is all about nourishment through food. Here, I take best practices from traditional "Mother Centered" cultures and offer them in a way that is practical for modern, millennial mamas. Have you wondered why some women ingest their own placentas? Are you hoping to avoid constipation and indigestion during your first few weeks as a mom? Learn the principles of what to eat, what to avoid, and how to avoid the common challenges that come with trying to feed yourself and your baby. Hint: Mama eats first! 

Part 5 contains chapters 20-23. Here, we dive deep in the social, emotional, and spiritual processing of the transition from maiden to mother. You will read stories that show how grieving is as powerful and important as celebrating. I also share insights on how the transition to parenthood can impact your partner and offer tools for protecting your relationship.

Part 6 wraps up the book with chapters 24- 26. This section helps to set you up for ways of being and systems for operating long after your forty days are complete. You also will enjoy a selection of recipes inspired by "Mother Centered" cultures.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Funds raised will go towards the following:

  • The editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in August 2021.
  • The cover design of my book. (The mockups you see currently are a placeholder!)
  • The layout design for the interior of my book (physical copy, ebook formats).
  • The copy editing for my book to polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication.
  • The launch & promotion efforts for my book when I ultimately publish this summer.

When I pre-sell 120 copies of Mama Eats First, I will publish a paperback and an ebook. When I pre-sell 150 copies, I will also publish a hardcover edition. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition and an audiobook.


I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish.
  • Your name will appear in the Acknowledgments section of my book.
  • You will receive early access to the Introduction and other excerpts from my book, with the opportunity to review them and give me early feedback.
  • You will have the opportunity to be involved in selecting my cover and title.
  • You will be invited to join my Author Community and get behind-the-scenes sneak peeks into the publishing process.
  • And much more!

 

About the Author

Elizabeth Schieffelin Liao serves as a Holistic Nutrition and Life Coach and Doula. She is the author of Mama Eats First (coming August 2021) and the I Am Grateful journal. She is also a yoga instructor, sound healer, and a multi-passionate wellness entrepreneur. Previously, she founded and ran a superfood smoothie company and a yoga studio in Shanghai. She has also led health retreats around the world.

Elizabeth is on a mission to empower women as they transition into motherhood and make their own unique, creative impact on the world. She is passionate about women’s health, happiness and self-expression, and increasing the access to holistic support that every mother deserves. After coaching many new moms and then giving birth to her own child, Elizabeth was drawn to the book writing process by a primary question: Why do some women seem to thrive as they transition to motherhood while others struggle? And what can we learn from other cultures? What elements of the postpartum experience are in our power to influence now?

Elizabeth is the proud mama of Lila Grace, an eight month old sunshine-spirited baby. Along with her husband and baby, Elizabeth loves to travel and explore new cultures. For the past seven years, Elizabeth was based in Shanghai, China and did remote living experiences in places like Spain, California and Puerto Rico. No matter where in the world she lands, Elizabeth has a big sweet tooth and can often be found in the kitchen experimenting with healthy versions of baked goods recipes. As you will learn in the book, Elizabeth has always had a strong drive to move and create. Her own mom recalls that Elizabeth was constantly bopping around as a tiny toddler, trying to do everything on her own, and saying "I do dat!" 

For more information, you can connect with Elizabeth at lizzyhealthcoach@gmail.com and at @bylizzy_ on Instagram. You can also learn more and visit her website www.lifebylizzy.com .
 

International Preorders

For international preorders, please send me a private message so that we can arrange shipping.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by including the cost of mailing and shipping the signed copies into each pre-order tier. 

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we ship the pre-order rewards to you as early as possible. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as to when my book will publish. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please share my pre-sale campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #mamaeatsfirst and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press, so that we can help amplify your efforts.
  • You can share my pre-sale campaign via Indiegogo at the top of the page.
  • Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it via text or direct message on social media.

 

Thank you so much for of all of your love and support!

With gratitude,


Elizabeth
